Management treat workers like trash, they do not listen or respond to serious safety issues. There is no safety culture, and the trainers are not competent.

Nothing special. Just worked there over the summer. There's about 10 games at the football game and I just did what was needed. Occasionally there would be concerts so I got to watch those which were cool.

fun place to work but a little strict at times. they need to think more about giving employees more benefits and to take better acre of them these days

Great atmosphere to work in !!! The employees are what make this a great place to work you can have fun all day on the job and still get the work done and everybody gets home safe

The City of Edmonton pays extremely well, however the management is getting increasingly toxic. Too many managers, frequently hiring their friends, forcing them to make up projects and initiatives to justify their jobs - at the expense of people who actually work in the field. Total disconnect between management and field workers.Increasingly moving away from full time jobs to "11 month postings" to ensure they don't have to give benefits and can drop you without justification.Potential advancement is blocked by education and accumulating seniority - almost no emphasis placed on merit.
pros: Excellent pay, good work life balance
cons: Toxic management, disconnect from upper management and workers in field. No value for hard workers.

text: Poor managementHad inexperienced people in positions which made the job twice as hard because of baby sitting or having to do your job as well as theirs and looking over your shoulder because they are friends with management.
cons: Poor job investigations and big favoritism.

text: I had a good experience, the on boarding process is on line, time consuming and you’re not paid for it so that’s a downfall. Unpaid training. Working there was great otherwise. Co workers were good people and the job itself was fun to do.
Decent job security if you can manage to secure a permanent position with the City. City work is unionized so you will always have work-life balance. Pay is fair with industry standards.

Contract work is great as a foot in the door, however it is very hard to get job security and peace of mind. A large organization like the City of Edmonton should do more to keep the people they hire.
Fun job while in university, only stressful thing was report cards and parents. Teaching kids was fun. Got to use skills learned in WSI to make a difference.
Overall good, a big organization that is trying to make major changes.  This puts lots of extra work on everyone.  Senior management is trying to take care of staff.

text: I worked hard and enjoyed my co workers.We got to know all about each other and why the city needs to employ more people to keep our roads and parks safe and clean
okay place to work. would try to find something with better pay. you are just a number here but you dont have to really care too much about the job. really hard to get in and land a perm posting.

Private company the best choice over this job. Here you are expected to work for free - stay late but never leave before 4:24- unpaid lunch and no breaks- eat on the run,You are expected to work for free to have the privilege to work for city- does no pay to work harder and killing time is the norm.Stay clear-

cons: No promotions, and no OT, expect you work for free or shorthand because it is a City job

text: Its a toss up. You might love it. You might hate it. Depends on where you end up you m8ght find yourself satisfied or might find yourself losing ambition and passion for your job. text: Fantastic place to work. Management is supportive and encourages collaboration while still ensuring the team has the resources to succeed. Extremely supportive throughout the pandemic to allow WFH.

text: Working at the City of Edmonton truly depends on the group you work in and the team around. Unfortunately, a few rotten apples spoil the bunch. If you are fortunate enough to work on a solid team ... congratulations.

Wages are far below average due to deductions. Extremely micromanaged no planning of work flow Safety culture is very weak Very weak leadership on all levels
pros: Some good techs but little teaching goes on.
cons: Terribly managed no flow of work and very clicky.

text: Most of the people at the City are dedicated and hard-working public servants, but I feel we are continually let down by senior management. Constant re-organizations over the last five years and near-annual budget "adjustments" (i.e. cuts) have led to burnout and poor morale. Senior management does a poor job of supporting and advocating for their employees.  Experiences vary widely depending on what department / branch people are working in. Little to no prospects for advancement - senior management seems intent on hiring from outside for anything Director level and up.Out-of-scope (non-union) employees have had a pay freeze for years and mediocre benefits compared to unionized employees.  The trade-off  in accepting lower compensation is supposed to be stability/job security and work/life balance, but the last few years have seen threats to jobs and people being asked to do more with less.If you are fortunate to have a good team, you will enjoy the work.
pros: Interesting and fulfilling work, Collaborative approach in most business areas, Good horizontal integration, Most employees are dedicated and hard-working
cons: Mediocre Benefits for non-union employees, Political environment, Absolutely no perks (bring your own coffee pods), Poor vertical communication

text: It was too chill and non chalant. The management was poor. They do not have a clue or proper training on how to mage employees. Not many people used the parks so you'll be bored a bit. But your supervisor would expect you to be working like there was a crowd.
Definitely a good place to work there’s room for advancement and lots of good people throughout the company aswell as nice lease trucks and supportive supervisors

Everyone is concerned about how they look to their superior. Quality of work comes second. Nepotism is a huge problem  at the city of Edmonton. Hours are horribly scheduled. They give you just enough so that you do not get shift differential. Probably why everyone quit.
cons: Work till 3 am most nights and they won't even give you 40 hrs a week which is why I quit.

text: There are problems there but they are trying to resolve them.Where I worked, my coworkers were excellent, my internal clients were respectful, and the leadership was generally competent and acknowledged my expertise.

Management is not respectful of the employees despite preaching how the City is a respectful workplace. They are backward thinkers, management heavy and are going backwards regarding work life balance. It's like working in the 1970's.

text: If you’re worried about the city of Edmonton wasting your tax dollars at every turn you are right to worry. The bureaucracy is unparalleled and the laziness and incompetence deeply rooted.

The city is moving to 40 hour w/week with no EDO program eff Jan 2022.  They tout themselves as an equal work life balance employer.  I guess no more.  It was a great program and really helped those with young and extended families and those with medical needs.   Although you have job security there is little to no advancement if your not liked through the grapevine.  Believe me managers talk.  They say there is growth but nothing happens in certain areas.  A lot of processes are changed without employee input and it's frustrating to fix things and find work arounds.  Department hiring has to be approved by the ELT (Executive leadership team) and they are more worried about their bonus than hiring.  Overtime is expected but not paid or rewarded. It's an attaboy reward.  Most people skip breaks and work past in order to keep things afloat.  When the hours change, and the EDO program is removed.  It will be a a horrible place.  And many of those unhappy now will leave.  It will go from an okay place to an awful place to work.
pros: Current work hours and EDO program
cons: 40 hour work week starting Jan 2022, End of EDO program, management too busy to care

text: Enjoyed my job as well as the people. Being a senior employee it was gratifying to  pass on my knowledge and experience to the younger person that will be filling my boots as I am moving on. Will miss you.All the power to ya! Your friend +Ex-coworker. MIC.

If you're into team work and used to collaborating this can be a difficult shift but you have weekly meetings with the your coworkers and visits from your supervisor so I got used to it. text: The work is both challenging and rewarding. Managers are self serving and always looking to find faults. Training is very good leaving no doubts in your mind what is expected.

text: My review doesn’t reflect other departments or the entire organization. Where I worked, at 311, the management was very supportive but the job itself was really stressful. The pay and benefits were good, most of your co-workers are helpful.

text: This was only a 4 week schooling CDI College prerequisite in completing my APA. The Supervisor was very nice to me and was very helpful in giving me advice on how to enter the job market at the City of Edmonton.

text: Enjoyed my time there! Highly recommended. I learned many new skills and was able to expand my knowledge of the rail industry. Great benefits, pay and perks.

text: A major employer with good benefits, pay, and culture.   If you don’t worry about leadership craziness and unneeded red tape, this is a good choice for you.

My experience at the City of Edmonton is a positive one.  Management is respectful and my team members are professional and hard working.  While our focus is on getting the job done efficiently, we also enjoy working together.

I have worked for the City of Edmonton for the past forty six years as of March 4th. I am very pleased with my job, however as I am looking to retire I am hoping to find a more relaxed job, such as an airport run. I would definitely recommend anyone to drive for the city.

when you understand how the games are played, then that's when you realize the culture. very sensitive place to work, being out spoken is a very big no, no. you will need to learn a whole new way and language to speak to people.

I am happy with the city of Edmonton and I will recommend it to a friend. it has great benefits and it has room to grow. great environment to be working at.

Always evolving technologies and expectations.Challenging but can be rewarding.Shift work can be a challenge at times, but there are positives.You are working with personnel from throughout the same organization, so there is an overall 'we are all on the same team' perspective.
Enjoy working with new people, learning opportunities and the growth of PM skills and abilities. This is excellent as it helps to build confidence in the work place and helps for future placement.

I learned alot working from the city, i did alot of work on a computer with work orders and such. and alot of grunt work. the enviroment at the shop I was located at was great.

Call Center is serving public for ALL municipal services, very fast working environment, changes constantly need to be able to adapt. Very well paid job.

I Enjoyed the job that i have done. The variety of different jobs you get to do within the job is nice. The management are great. It is sad that work ethic does not have much value in whether you get to stay employed and whether you get laid off. I am sad that there is no job security here.
This is one of the best companies I have worked for. My immediate supervisor was very supportive for growth and development. Very respectful place to work with good compensation package.

Provide detailed information about the facility, programs, products, and services to patrons and special needs visitors both in person and over the phone Process program registrations and facility bookings using CLASS and RAMS computer softwarePromote health and wellness through the sale of special products, services, and membershipsCollect facility admission fees, handle cash, and prepare daily depositsPerform administrative duties such as word processing, data entry, and generating inventory reports

Its been a pleasure to work for the city.Great people and management that I deal with, I look forward to going to work, and feel great when I get home. its nice to have a feeling of accomplishment and safety at the end of the day.

Management is really bad, Pay is alight, good work life balance, very old school, management is not progressive minded, fails to value good employee, lots of unnecessary politics

It's a good job, once you get in. Dont miss too much time, and they work on keeping you. Lots of room for advancement, if you follow the leads. However, it is also a good job to retire from if you get permanent. Most jobs are temporary.

JOB as security guard in Edmonton tower involves directing people to the  right  department and it involves patience, energy and very good interpersonal skills .people from all different background and culture come to the city for different types of problems or services they need .security guard has a important role to ensure a very peaceful environment in and around the city offices  .I did my part to the best of my abilities and performed pretty well .

The work was not complicated and our lead trusted us to get our assigned work done so no micro-management. The interviewer did lie and say there were benefits for us contract workers which was totally false which made took the shine of the ok pay. Don't expect more than 5 to 6 months of work even if the posting and interviewer says more. Don't believe for a second that the City cares about you or that you're going above an beyond. Seems like most positions are now Temporary Up To 39 hours so they can cut hours, pay and benefits. Morale is garbage.

Was hired as an Animal Control Officer. They extended my contract for up to a year and a half, during which time the requirements for a permanent position changed and they did not provide adequate time to prepare and obtain the new requirements and I was laid off when my contract ended. They tried to end my contract early. There was extreme bullying and favoritism by management. A year and a half and no vacation leave or health benefits because I was considered a temp employee. I put in my time and was treated like I was nothing. Was even asked to train my replacement before my time was up. Was given senior level responsibilities. Not allowed to join committees due to temp status. Lost my parking area due to temp status. If I hadn't gotten laid off, I probably would ave had to go on stress leave. I loved my job and put my heart and soul into it, had exemplary performance, but still no support and was shown the door. Very traumatic experience. Beware of Edmonton Animal Control.
It was an amazing environment and staff. Everybody was very helpful so the workload wasn't ever too stressful or overwhelming. I gained lots of experience and exposure to different career fields.
Very stressful with high quotas and critical time constraints. Varying climate conditions with lots of driving in tight quarters and varying production loads.
working there i realized quickly there were quotas and output levels that were guarded by the staff and it works good for them. The available OT was a big catch
Loved working there 4+ years ! No permanent positions though! Meaning no Pension vacation or benefits. Yet they hire a manager every week and they all start with it all.

Surprised how sensitive the City administration caters to paranoid, poor work ethic employees. Managers can't get a full day's effort due to smoke breaks outside the coffee breaks and too much socializing. When being asked to focus on work, employees threaten that you are harassing them, and threaten a grievance. Employees who suck up to their bosses are rewarded when they gossip about others  Personnel ( HR)  provides poor support to supervisors and managers, as they worry about grievances, rather than helping managers coach employees toward success and better work culture. Good workers are not rewarded. We just shake our heads and roll our eyes and look for an opportunity elsewhere. The City Clerk's area was the worst area, and the Regulatory Boards under the City Clerk area.
I like working at The City of Edmonton. If you want to work in The City, You need to keep applying there.------------------------------------------------------------

it sad just how much tax payer money is wasted with the way the city hires for certain positions.ive built roads my whole life and i was put in turf. i can run any piece of equiptment and they put a weed wacker in my hands.
Had a couple of fun work partners you get alot of benefits working for city of edmonton , the management is the best ever , and work hours are as convenient as ever

Corporate workplace but everyone works as a team, co-operative and friendly workplace. Management levels are always looking for their employees. Have fun, celebration, training, toastmaster, etc. happen in the City of Edmonton workplace. I love this place and very glad to get an opportunity as a Co-op employee.
Great place to work.... I actually miss it. I didn’t think I could do split shifts for the next 10 years. Depending on seniority,(badge number) equates the shift you can sign. 🤷‍♂️
Enjoyed working with the people on my team, we all got along and it made the job and time go by quickly.  Going to work at a place where you have nice people to work with made it easy.
Good place to work, hard to get a permanent spot though. If you don't know how to network, you won't get very far. I have nothing else to add but this box wants 150 words minimum.
Loved the hard work, and the people I worked with. Lots of hard hours but very rewarding work. Not much room to advance until you're provisional (1944 hours).. but for seasonal work its fantastic.
Supervisor and crew in my yard were fantastic. Great Moral and attitudes. Very much enjoyed working with them all. I encourage young people to apply as it takes a while to move up.

I imagine the city is much like any other very large bureaucracy.  It's all about politics and appearances.  If that means that someone needs to be a scapegoat; so be it.  Most of the rules are from the 70's so they are incredibly out of touch and only enforced if they want to persecute someone.

COE is a great place to work IF you're placed in the right department. Most of the staff are friendly and nice BUT if you're easily offended be prepared for some mild bullying. The pay could be better but it will be if you land a permanent job. Overall one of the better jobs I have had and WAY better than EPCOR who just lie to you and use you.
Management is really bad, Pay is alight, good work life balance, very old school, management is not progressive minded, fails to value good employee, lots of unnecessary politics
good place to work ..flexible hours..decent pay..no benefit for seasonal..i will recommend city ..good place to work.......................................
was ok lots of data entry and paper information some were hard to read lots of entries for pay roll but was an enjoyable job it was not really fast paced lots of down time

I really enjoyed working here. The supervisors are accommodating, super nice, and patient with you. I enjoyed playing with the children at Green shack, and being active everyday. Great environment and company to work for

1in 5 city employees claim to have been harassed.  3.5 managers for every employee.  Poisonous work atmosphere. Good wages and benefits. The entire management team is a old boys club made up of retired military personnel.
I have only volunteered with the City of Edmonton, but all the people who work there are nice and collaborative. My volunteering was only for special events.
I got to work with little children as a volunteer, and build special relationships with them as I got to organize activities for them as it was really enjoyable for me to volunteer there every day.
signed on as a rap student and I never felt mistreated. excellent management. they are understanding the harder part of my job was dealing with calcium chloride trucks during the winter months
In Canada you are innocent till proven guilty. In transit you are guilty until you prove yourself innocent. A lot of stress in position. But can sign work to meet your lifestyle.
Working for the city of Edmonton was great, I was always kept busy and learned new skills while on the job. This is why I stayed for 10 years, highly recommend working for the city.

no full time anymore. wouldnt recommend if you want a full time career. at least in parks/roads department.if you want part time or seasonal work fine go for it. have  have lots of schooling if you think u have a chance to go anywhere with the city. no benifits or paid vacition unless your permanent full time.and the union does nothing except take your money ever two weeks.

Experienced severe Harrassment along with several other co workersand quit in an email after 30 years.  The others filed grievances with the Union but after seeing how bad that went I chose to leave. The problem is always the same people but for some reason they don't seem to care. There are serious bullies in sustainable development and staff are leaving because of them.

very lazy workers and management, if your a lazy person will be good however if you find the day goes by faster if you work through it you will find the day drags on. When i say lazy i mean no one does anything for the majority of the day, so you really get to know your coworkers and it can be fun if thats what your looking for. Also impossible to get fired or reprimanded aafter you work there two years, one guy would come in an hour late every single day and never got fired.

Decades of poor management and poor financial accountability has created this unique mess of a city. It is bloated with over 16000 employees. That's an absurd number for the population.  Deputy city managers run little fiefdoms and don't work together. This costs the tax payer money and results in poor service. In fighting is the common practice with everyone afraid of being challenged in terms of how and what they do. Management stab each other in the back in order to safeguard themselves. People don't want to change things even though things are abysmal when it comes to wasted processes and resources. Favorites are picked based on how well they put on a show!  It's all about appearance... you don't have to actually deliver anything!  In fact, make something, even videos that amuse senior management and you've got it made.  Staff contributions are ignored and credit is taken by managers. The CAO has no clue what is going on other than whether or not her contract will be renewed so that she can buy things for her retirement.
pros: You can do nothing; if that's your game
cons: Zero satisfaction and growth for your career

text: Worked for city for 6 years. If you are friends with your manager great if not then dont plan on being advanced cause they already have that planned.Hours and future are myth they change and anything happens. Its like highschool all over again with the culture at work.
A secure and growing employer, becoming more aware of Diversity, and to practice it.  Diverse areas of interest for someone looking to stay and grow with an organization.

City of Edmonton is the best workplace I ever worked for. There is a positive environment all around and people are very supportive. I love the company and always be glad for the knowledge I gained there.

High work volume with huge responsibility allowing little time for regular breaks which can affect ones health.  Regular unexpected terminations of middle management resulting in regular chaos, miscommunication and actual "fist fighting" among business units as they are trying to do their jobs without proper direction.  Bullying, harassment is common place and lack of supports prohibit one from doing a professional, stand up job (if this is what you desire)!  Favoritism is also common place which may prohibit one from advancing internally despite possessing quals, just a toxic place to work in general if you "care" about your own personal performance! Lots of staff off work for stress so be prepared to pick up the pace! Senseless IT programs without value and the "We are One City" is a joke as you won't know what your own business unit is doing and those are always changing resulting in way too many little departments with lots of middle and upper management to run these department (ie.10 upper/middle managers, to run a little department of 10???) Top heavy in management all lacking leadership!

A typical day at work involves inspecting the entire job site. Addressing issues withe form work, reviewing construction materials, reviewing grades and elevations, meeting with the construction crew.  Meeting with Planning PM to discuss updates.

A good place to work for gaining experience but too political, you need to have a good relationship with management in order to be permanent or to move up your level. Unionized yet you can only get help if you are permanent employee, if you are temp no chance to get support. Too many favouritism, invisible discrimination. The saying is really correct, it is not what you know but who you know.
Finish work at 3. Friendly and fun employees. BBQ provided in the summers. Foremans are great, respectful and acknowledge hard working labourers. Over time is nice, as its double-time
Management is really bad, Pay is alight, good work life balance, very old school, management is not progressive minded, fails to value good employee, lots of unnecessary politics

Lots of pressure.  If you don't have multiple projects on the go, they act like your not working hard enough.  Never had to work from home but it was often hard to shake off the stress after each work day.
pros: Earned day off (EDO) program- every third Friday
cons: Management has had no raise in 3 years

text: I enjoyed going to work everyday.  There is plenty of training. I learned alot of different skills and brushed up on some of my skills I already had.  It is a wonderful working environment.
An amazing job for students in the summer. Only last till September. Not very hard work and get to plant flowers and take care of them. Some gross parts when cleaning parks/litter up.

Working here was an exercise in futility. Management is completely cut off from the work done by front-line staff. Advancement opportunities were few and far between. I had numerous toxic managers who were moved to other areas instead of being dismissed.
enjoyed my time there. some people made the work enjoyable others did not. good leadership and good chances for advancement. hours weren't the best but they were acceptable.
Very good work culture and team leader, the pay is low and advancement opportunity is not too great. The job is  part time basis so shifts are not always guaranteed.

This is a City owned facility and it's rolenis vital to the recreation provides for locals and tourists. The food is overpriced but there is plenty to see and enjoy. As an Indigenous Interpreter I wear a costume and help the visitor to back in time to imagine what lives people had in previous generations. Everyone has a family and Fort Edmonton does a great job in bringing some value to Canadian history.
cons: Overpriced admission, overpriced food, should no longer have wagon rides with horses and have no pigs or sheep.

text: was always a very easy going place to work at. Pay was very good for a student who needed to save money during the summer months and couldn't work in the winter.

My day at work involved working on the phones to help provide the citizens with various information. While it was a fast-paced job, my co-workers and managers always made sure the environment was stress-free as possible. The compensation was more than adequate and allowed me to manage my expenses comfortably

I worked for the Greenshack program this summer during the INTENSE smoke outside. Levels were in the high 8's and 9's all day and only until it hit a 10 would the management let us go home. 8 hours in a level 9 is just as harmful as an hour in 10. Not just for me, but my kids as well. I should not have to hide in my car if working at my jo is making it hard to breathe or I feel sick.

Work is work. My co-workers are great. I have not learned much, I provide a benefit to the City for a salary. That's about it. Upper management and the City Manager are a complete joke. My direct managers are fine, although no one has the balls to do anything about any problems that may arise. The hardest part of the job is dealing with old farts that should retire or get with the future in the fact that not everyone has to be in an office from 9-5 now.  There are opportunities to work remotely and save the City of Edmonton a ton of money.  The City has become extremely cheap lately as well. Management hasn't received raises in 4 years and the Union is looking like it might be following suit.  With the cost of inflation, not receiving a raise is actually a demotion or pay cut.  The most enjoyable part of the job is the co-workers and the fact that we all hate working for the City and can agree on that.  Advancement is near impossible unless you know the right people.
cons: Work is not in any way fulfilling

text: Worse place to work. To much politics an favoritism. Supervisors are idiots and disrespectful also dont care about there employees!Dont waste time there unless you wanna be fired afer 11 months contract. Stay away

This has been such a fun job, and I will be sad when I have to leave. The children's experience team is awesome, and so friendly. Supervisors are very encouraging and supportive and offer advice when needed.

I worked for the city of edmonton for four years, no chance of being made permanent , would have layoffs the moment it snowed, very racist, my co-workers smoked pot then got into equipment and vehicles and operated them also they stole everything in sight, would recommend you never work there.
ALOT of politics. Having to kiss up to management, friends of managers get precedence and special treatment. All in all, they are more focussed on money than employees.
Currently the face of the company. Enjoy being around people. Scanning and assisting various customers. Multi tasking and the ability to speak in different languages.
have to work basically 2 whole years part time to get a raise so it takes a long time. Also the shifts you get you’re completely stuck with. Bad management

Being outside everyday was a huge highlight.  I do like being in charge of enforcing bylaws.  I took pride in my job. Wasn't paid that much as we were contracted out of a security company and not law enforcement.
pros: Health benefits, working outside, made great friends

text: I loved working for the city .Just a few things that bug me and that was the drive to work from Camrose all my money was going to fuel . and shift work . I thought i only be on shift through the winter for a couple of years its not going on 5 yrs and it doesn't help that i have a little family to take care of. Once your in a postion with the city its hard to move up or down on the ladder . So your basically stuck in the middle and managment won't do much about it. I love driving truck  its can be enjoying at times and exhusting at other time cause it just you in the truck and your mind will start to wonder .
Great workers and a great work environment. Easy and to the point instructions and a good idea if what jobs needed to be completed per day. Would highly recommend for a summer job.
Management is really bad, Pay is alight, good work life balance, very old school, management is not progressive minded, fails to value good employee, lots of unnecessary politics

Its a good job, management needs work.  Lots of discrimination within the city. I thought it would be a job i would have till i retired.  i worked for 5 years and still didn't get a perminate postion, due to a hiring freeze mandated from the mayor.
Great for anyone wanting to work with a group of people as a summer job.  Mainly involved doing minor horticulture and driving around getting to different positions

The City has a lot of perks, don’t get me wrong. Such as good pay for easy work, good crews, appreciation brunches and dinners, etc. But at the same time, there are lots of negatives. They do not hire permanent employees often so I know people who have been with the city 10yrs and have no benefits or job security. It is very cliquey - one of the upper hiring managers told me TO MY FACE that they only rehire if the person got along with their crew, was punctual and adhered to all policies. One of the policies is that temporary workers (which most of us are) only get 2 sick days per 11 month period and if you go over that you are no longer considered a “recommended rehire” and you are bumped to “conditional rehire”. Managers and team leaders play favorites, and if you aren’t one of them you are pretty much doomed if you hoped your career would lie within the city. They don’t care about work ethic, just if you suck up to management.

My experience at The City was long-lived and very boring. Everything I went to school for and learnt, I used about 2% of my knowledge. There was hardly any work and no training or instruction on how to do the tasks given. However it was a special experience and not all businesses are run the same.

Excellent company to work for. If you're looking for a job in the Edmonton are area you wont find a better job. If you want competitive wages, excellent benefits and a good work/home life they are the employer you're looking for
A great job for students over the summer. There is absolutely potential for individuals to move be promoted if they choose to stay on after they graduate.
Good management and good coworkers. Fair and reasonable place to work. Good work space and good corporate culture. Love the pot luck lunches and food by staff

I have not experienced the amount of disrespect from management  & coworkers ever in my life until becoming a city employee , it use to be a great place to work. It has turned in to a very stressed filled environment . there is no  communication, only dictatorship & A very  demeaning culture  . This is no localized, it is wide spread though out the city of Edmonton  from general labours to upper management , it is very disappointing .

Working with City of Edmonton was a excellent experience of my career. -wonderful multicultural environment at workplace-Cooperative and helping senior management staff-Lots of growth opportunities

-Misogynistic Culture of fear, humiliation and harassment fostered by and supported by upper management.-Confusion and poor planning-Nepotism and cronyism is the norm.-Management treats temporary workers like pawns, whose schedules, place of work, and job descriptions can be changed without asking or any notification-Temporary labourers are often given less than one day for notification of layoff -The culture of gossip is extremely toxic. Especially amongst management.  Both Direct and upper management-Gives very little; almost no training on how to do the actual job you were hired for
I was working through randstad agency.but job atmosphere was excellent. i was not on permanent position.so they were  treating as a helping hand guest. They were happy with my service.
I have worked at the COE for 7 years and it offers great job security and decent pay and benefits. While there are opportunities for growth they don't always seem to available.

It felt like the City's motto should have been what more can we take from our employees. There was a lot of hard work with little benefits and good luck if you are in a position that deals with the public. They feel like they own you because "they pay your salary". I have never been treated worse at a job by the clients.

If you enjoy feeling like you accomplished something in a day I wouldn't recommend CoE. If you want to punch a clock and float, great place.  Everything needs multiple approvals, union workers are invulnerable where management has nothing to review poor business practices. Change is rampant so you have to constantly navigate new procedures that no one knows, if someone doesn't want to do something they just pass the buck to another department and send you on a goose chase. Very frustrating and hard to stay motivated.
pros: Many good people that try, slightly less hrs/week
cons: Constant change and shuffling, many bad people who dont try, super process heavy

text: good to work forlearned lots and had some really good supervisors learned lots of interesting things and the pay was very welllots of opportunities to grow and better yourselflots of courses offered
I found working for the City was a great experience, working out side meeting new people the hours are great, wages were good, I look forward to returning next year

text: I worked  there as a teenager during highschool. Was a great experience.Was a sales clerk and cashier. Staff incentives for higher salesLoved the sales atmosphere and dealing with customersCapable of fast past environment

The city of Edmonton was a waste of time. they waste tax payer money sitting and doing nothing. they fix stuff only so they break again. the city of Edmonton is full of losers. and the transit CEO is an idiot i could do a better job drunk

The job security and benefits are good, but the companies culture has taken a nose dive in recent years. So it depends what you value in your work life.
cons: Culture, work life balance, communication between management and staff

text: Staff able to deal with emerging issues in a very professional manner. Amazing opportunity to feel you are truly serving the citizens in this public facing organization.

text: when I worked for this employer, I worked there for 12 years - I was overworked, underpaid, and underappreciated.  The management was horrible, and I was pigeon-holed into a position regardless of all the hard work that I did.  I will never encourage anyone to work for the City of Edmonton
Great place to work for. Would welcome opportunity to go back. Met a lot of great people. I would recommend this company to anyone who meets there qualifications.

I had the opportunity of working with friendly employees in a great and fun working atmosphere. I felt mutual respect among co-workers as well as upper management.
Only job I could have at the time so i think it was good i really dont know why i have to do this review so yeah i really hope i can work at the REC room

The culture and management absolutely suck. Expect long work days, harassment and abuse by managers and supervisors. They will create and maintain fake social media profiles about you and use that against you if they can't find any other means to fire you. Then they get the Mayor involved to launch fake investigations on you.

At the start of every day, we communicate through Google Hangout and we let everyone know where are we going, where we are, jobs that's outstanding, jobs completed, safety issues yada yada. Working here, I learned to appreciate more and value my coworkers as they are really helpful in times I need them and even if I don't, they still offer their help. We look after each other that what makes it a great team to be in it. A management that cares for the well being of their subordinates is number one in my book. Jobs hard but it get easier when everybody tries to pitch in to help. The part that I enjoy the most is my supervisor is always there to help, listen, appreciate, joke around and just a down-to-earth person  who's really selfless no matter who he's dealing with.

There was minimal support from Supervisors, they expected a lot for very little pay. Management never took ownership of their mistakes just threw their staff under the bus. It was the most disorganized place I ever worked

The management is very helpful and kind and understanding. Things are a bit of a mess but that it due to changes from higher up the ladder I basically come in in the evenings and on weekends, grab a truck, a water plants alone. it is nice to work alone, and also a bit lonely at times. My manager always says she is available if i need help or have questions.  I have learned how to drive a big truck! pretty exciting.

Complete lack of respect for management staff. No effective, reliable or truly independent resources for complaint reporting. Lots of political backstabbing. Promotion based on favouritism, gender & incompetence is rampant.
cons: culture, work life balance is non-existent, only lip service paid to policies, incompetence & favouritism due to yes-man attitude is promoted rather than honesty, integrity & truthfulness

text: If you care about the job and or try to do a good job management will just keep adding tasks onto you until you snap. The culture is really really really bad! They will cut the jobs that actually do the real work and put the money into a photo shoot.

text: i loved the professionalism, the people and the work environment. the management was nice and worked well with me. i enjoyed the jobs and tasks that were asked of me.

With the Leaders in Training program it gave me a lot of experience and skills on how to be a leader for my everyday life. The hardest part of the job is not being listen to when given an opinion and the manager just brush it off.

The job itself was never the issue, it was always the management.  They're pretty sticky about regulations, and often, because of their monolithic policy, penalize unfairly for what would be a nonissue in most other places.
the green shack and flying eagle program taught me how to be a leader and how to talk different ages of people to get to know them and learn what they enjoy

text: I have worked at Grand Trunk Leisure Centre for the past 3 and half years and it has been an overall enjoyable working experience. I have kind and friendly co-workers that makes this facility a nice place to work.

text: Great place to work. As a Traffic Signals Tech your day was busy and when a detour came in, you had to work fast to get it out the door. And documentation was very important to maintain.

not a heavy workloadas with any bureaucracy, work and change is very slowworkplace culture is decent, some employees are there for the free ride, and others are frustrated at the apparent slow pace of progress

I enjoyed working with the City of Edmonton as it was a comfortable and respectable working environment. There are many benefits along with work life balance.
Excellent Company to work for.I never left the company, but the company has undergone new management to EPCOR. I had to transition to EPCOR. Work culture is great.

Everyday in CPIC is different. Some teams also do team building activities outside of work, which has been a lot of fun.  Management I do not find it be very good, in my opinion there is lots of favoring and bullying.   Hardest part of the job is the shiftwork and 12 hour shifts, they are long and draining, however the work and being a vital part of the policing in Edmonton is a huge benefit!!.

political and management is discriminatory. for a city operation there is a lot of favoritism. work hard and under valued as employee. men rule woman work even harder.

Was employed only for the election and enjoyed working it and meeting new people.  It was very well organized and would definitely work it again.  City of Edmonton is a company I would really enjoy working with.

text: The culture behind the job is fine, the city promotes safe work. Management can be very unorganized and patrons can get abusive, which is the hardest part of the job. The city does pay way better than anyone else in the industry.
very friendly and accommodating staff that perform fantastic on the job training. As a supply chain major, I learned a lot about the warehousing/logistics industry.

The City of Edmonton provides amazing benefits and salary but doesn't have much work for its student employees. It can be difficult to find enough work to get through the day at times depending on who your supervisor is

A very laid back and easy job to do. I personally did not enjoy working there at all. The work in itself was not bad, the people i worked with were not good at all. There is so much drama and behind the back secrets, it felt like i was in high school again. I think they need to fix how they do their hiring and fix upper managements decisions. a lot of times we were wondering why we were doing something when there is either more important things to do or a better way of doing it.  ex. we were picking/cutting and spraying herbicide on already dead weeds that have already seeded out for the next season.-- to do so is absolutely pointless, we should be preparing residual herbicide to kill weeds before they germinate next year!
cons: only 8 hour days with no overtime

text: good work balancebetter benefitsnice people to work with.very accessiblerelax environmentlearning a lot of thingsroom for growthvery transparent

text: Working with the kids at the park green shacks made everyday new and interesting. Listening to all the stories they had to tell was very enjoyable. I got to meet and get to know new children everyday.When I would teach a child something new or give them helpful advice on a problem, seeing the smiles on their faces afterwards was the most rewarding part of the job.The staff and management team were always happy and willing to exchange tips and advice to any issues or concerns that happened on site. We all worked very well together, and nobody felt excluding in any aspect of the job.

I worked for DATS for about 6 months. The job itself was great. Hard work, challenging, rewarding. Received several client commendations on my work.  There was a lot of bullying, harassment and racism at the scheduling/operations level however. Supervisory staff were incompetent and arrogant. Management blindly followed supervisory staffs lead. I was assaulted by a client on video and called the police after defending myself. I was completely cleared of ANY wrongdoing by the Edmonton Police Service. However, I was told by Senior management (before police or DATS had completed their investigation) that it would have never happened if I had acted appropriately (victim blaming) and my probationary period was extended. Senior management also encouraged me to look at other employment options within the City of Edmonton at this time. This resulted in complete loss of trust and faith in the management and a downward spiral in my work and all aspects of my life. Supervisors who now had decided to micromanage my work (because I refused to meet with them without union representation after earlier harassment) made my job much more difficult. Eventually my stress and the pressure I was under to perform caused me to make poor decisions such as getting a photo radar ticket in an empty bus late at night in my now extended probationary period. I was let go. If I wasn't in extended probation I would have gotten a one day suspension and had to pay the fine. As many DATS operators have had to do. Everyone makes mistakes. My mistake was thinking that the Union I was a part of could do anything - more...

Where to begin. The shop is a mess, you spend a lot of time looking for shop tools and equipment. No time is provided to clean up the shop so you constantly work in other peoples messes. The parts department is useless and you frequently get wrong parts even when providing the old parts as samples. Don't bother asking foremans for technical assistance because they have no experience and they're not even heavy duty techs. Knowledge and hard work gets you no where. You must know people in managment to move up. The less experience you have and the less you know about your job the better the chance of being promoted. All of the paperwork gets completed by the technicians so not sure what the foremans do. They frequently use works like "efficiency" and "productivity" yet nobody seems to know what it means. The rotation schedule is insane giving you 8 nights in a row with no overtime in the winter. There's little to no overtime unless you manage to work on stats. I think of it as opposite land since all the wrong people get promoted,   and nobody cares about anything and 6 months technical experience is good enough to be foreman because your buddy is in a higher position. Don't bother applying for the internal job postings because they already know who they want and create a posting to avoid suspicions. You pay for the benifits and they're useless and expensive. There are way too many deductions on pay checks, benefits, union dues, pension and charitable donations that nobody knows what it's for but it's mandatory. Once you take the pension your benefits get cut off. You have to pay - more...
cons: Bad rotation schedule, disorganized, too many pay deductions, inexperienced management

My thirty (30) year career with The Edmonton Fire Department, provided me with personal challenges, beginning as a Recruit Firefighter, and concluding my career as a senior officer of the Department. I was very fortunate to not only enjoy and respect the people and officers that I worked with but to thoroughly enjoy the nature of the work that we complected as a team.CUSTOMER SERVICE  was paramount to the success of the Department, an objective that I took very serious personally. Whether assisting people at emergency or non emergency scenes or by representing the department at various educational opportunities or committee associations,  representing the Edmonton Fire Department was always a pleasure and my personal responsibility..As a member of the Department there was every opportunity to learn at least one new thing every shift.I felt I was able to demonstrate the following attributes which aided me being successful as both a fire fighter and fire officer;Mental - I had the mental capability to perform the jobPhysical- I had the necessary physical capabilities for the positionMoral - I have a good sense of community and public service. The hardest part of my job was my decision to retire as my career was like working with a family for all those years.
Great work life balance, always very grateful being in the union and having great salary/benefits negotiated for on our behalf.

Worked on a knowledge management tool for the employees of the city to use. We consolidated information from different sources and inputed the information to the tool. It's the reason I had to go on LTD.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the comradeship between all the drivers.

text: Core group of dedicated upbeat employees with a strong team work culture.Being able to multi task is a definite requirement for this position. All levels of management will be present at one time or another in a positive and supportive role. Never the same day twice.

The City of Edmonton is a great place to work.  There are great people and the work/life balance is excellent.  There's an excellent benefits package as well.

Good place to work if your already set for life or looking to retire its not for young guys trying to buy a house and whatever else, There was not a lot of overtime so it was time for me to move on

I enjoyed the atmosphere Loved the job itself , but management was poor

Awesome place to work. Great people and managers.Great opportunities to learn new things. Lots of Career advancement opportunities.

A typical day at work is very busy and never dull. learn new things all the time. I learned how to work a lot of the City of Edmonton's in- house programs and expanded my knowledge of the Microsoft office suite program. For the most management was great.  Sometimes it was hard to meet with management when i had a question to ask and would have to wait for them quite awhile.  I would ask as many of my co-workers the question that I had to ask my boss, and they were very helpful.  I would only go to my boss if none of my co-workers knew the answer to my question about certain projects etc. Sometimes clients/customers wanted certain things done immediately.  Due to some procedures, sometimes we  couldn't always do things as immediate as the customer would have liked, but i would always do my best to meet the customers expectations. Most enjoyable part of the job for me was dealing with the customers, I thoroughly enjoy working with the public.
cons: Not being able to meet the customers expectations as fast as they wanted, but due to rules and regulations, things were out of my control.

text: I enjoyed the people that I worked with.  Was a fun atmosphere.

My days are long, but rewarding.  Building strong relationship is the/my key to success.  Accountability shouldn't be expected unless paired with authority.  Daily goal is helping my co-workers succeed in their work/job/life.  Managing scope creep is the hardest part of my job.  The most enjoyable part of my job is the satisfaction I feel when a project plan has been adopted, because I know it is a solid plan due to my strong understanding of the connectivities and dependencies within the organization.
It's a good place to balance you work and life, especially for staff need to take care of little kids or other family members.
Worked with some great people who I am still friends with today.
People are so friendly and helpful. Lots of resources to learn new things and Opportunity to show you skills.
Great work environment, excellent managment, multicultural team.
Amazing team spirit, uncapped potential for career and personal growth.
cons: Hard to get your foot in the door.

A typical day at work would be digging underground by hand for the cities drainage system, with the use of a jackhammer and shovel. We learn how to deal with different ground conditions as well as how to manage time so we finish proper footage in a day. One of the main reason I am looking to further my career else where is  because of management. This department in my opinion is poorly disorganized, does not value young driven employees and shows no interest or gives opportunities to advance a career within the department. My co-workers are usually great to work with, hard workers with drive for towards an honest days work. one of the hardest parts of my job would be operating a jackhammer for upwards to twelve hours a day 5-7 days a week, and the most enjoyable part of my job is working with a great crew and learning new ways to make the job and day go a little easier.
pros: benefits medical and dental, and vaction pay
cons: very labour intensive work, low opportunites for advancment in a career

overall a pretty good place to work the money isn't that great for the  job you do but the people make it a much better environment to work so that's the bounus cool things to work on and get to use .

if you can get a city of edmonton job then take it! it was a great place to work and the p[ay is also really great: )

Ever football game I would arrive at the stadium, we would have an employee meeting then off to the designated gate. over the course of the game hundreds of people came through each gate. we were responsible to scanning tickets, if there were issues with the tickets we had to direct people to ticket booths. we were also responsible for directing to seats, consignment, transportation and other such places. we also had to make sure that no alcohol left the premises. the hardest part was being exposed to the elements, but the other employees were a joy to works with.
pros: A free hot dog and beverage

text: I have enjoyed working for the City of Edmonton for nearly 5 years. Over this time I have moved from a swimming instructor, to a lifeguard and over the past 2 years I have now been working as a pool service person nearly half the time I am at work. I have always been mechanically inclined and my supervisors have seen this and used me to their advantage. I am often in charge of heading back washes as well as completing pump and filtration system maintenance. If my supervisors are not around. I am always the one that my fellow co workers call upon if there is a mechanical or water chemistry related issue.  I enjoy the problem solving aspect of it dealing with our complex filtration systems and find a sense of satisfaction when I can get things running smoothly.
pros: Excellent management and job security, a great feeling of belonging.
cons: Hours can some times be unreliable, some weeks I'll work 50 hours a week and other's 30 hours per week.

text: If a low skill level requirement, and little to achieve at work interest you, this is your place!
very good company, they reward hard work. education and job promotion is always offered.

I am very happy with how the city treats its workers. Management is great. Great group of co-workers. The hardest part of the job is dealing with difficult customers. The most enjoyable part of the job is interacting with the public.
Very physical but love it, keeps you in shape and gives you a great experience.

Trained for two days and volunteered for two weeks. It was very fun but tiring at the same time, starting from early morning hours to evening hours. Met a lot of new people and entertained many young children, volunteering at a playground green shack program is an awesome experience.
pros: I can work there if I wanted to
cons: Boiling hot days in a metal green shack

text: A wonderful place to work. Everyday is a new experience. Meeting new people everyday is an unique experience. Surrounded by a wonderful group of coworkers make the place our second home.

1st of all the pay is not great. So if you need to make a great deal of money, apply elsewhere.  The City is big on covering its butt legally so you'll be taking courses and going to safety meetings etc none of which has made much difference in the 30 years that I have worked there.  Summers are very busy at Parks. Winters get busier with snowfall. It is difficult to get good employees because so many are very young and don't really want to earn their pay. The City is over managed. There are far more bosses than workers and many of the bosses have zero experience on the ground yet make all the decisions, usually without asking the people who know- the Crew leaders.  If you have a degree, even in Baking, you could be immediately bumped up the ladder. Actual work experience is not necessary. You will rarely see a boss with a tool in their hands If a well run organization is important to you-FLEE! The answer to every problem in the City of Edmonton is more administration! Never more boots on the ground. Chaos rules. The hardest part of the job is doing it in a fashion that I know is not efficient but orders from above require me to do it that way anyway.  The most enjoyable part of the job is camaraderie among staff and the 4 ten hour/day shifts. 3 day weekends and all stat holidays off.
cons: Extremely poor management and patronage postings for brown nosers common.

text: Great support if you get a good group of people to work with. Otherwise can be straining.

I enjoy being a City Employee.  However, the field in which I work has no job security, no benefits, no chance to advance or move up, and the pay is only good if you sacrafice your entire schedule to working insane and sporadic hours.  The co workers and employers are amazing people that love what they do.  They are driven and passionate about the health industry.  However, this career path does not mesh well with my goals in life.
pros: Free membership to City Recreation Facilities
cons: Sporadic hours, no job security, no benefits, medicore pay

text: I only worked in a very small section of the City of Edmonton's expansive labour force. My experience was a good one, Unions meant I was always taken care of and well payed. There were no typical days in my position, every day was different, unpredictable. What starts as a quiet day can easily erupt into a flurry of public complaints, inquiries from the Mayor or City Councillors. Working with 30+ union staff was also a challenge especially when things go sideways. Interesting work but stressful at times.   My duties as the Vegetation Management Supervisor and Integrated Pest Management Coordinator included the following:  • Provided leadership in developing, implementing and managing annual work plans including recruiting required seasonal staff to implement annual work plans and capital projects• Built effective teams by providing coaching and counselling, organized staff orientation, safety training, attendance management, performance reviews and educational development. The most enjoyable part of the job was my accomplishments, • Led the Parks Vegetation Management Team in the continuous reduction of pesticide use from 1999 to 2012 leading to the Charles Labatiuk Award for Environmental Excellence• Instrumental in the development and implementation of the City’s Good Growing Neighbours public education pesticide reduction program• Forged partnerships with the County of Strathcona, City of St. Albert and City of Leduc in joining and contributing to the Good Growing Neighbours program • Represented the Vegetation Management section and the Good Growing Neighbours public education campaign as media spokesperson conducting television, radio and print media interviews• Worked with the Edmonton Naturalization Group (ENG), various - more...

i work in the waste management dept the moral is pretty close to the worst I've ever seen. Your day to day job will destroy your body over time and when you are used up you are told it's time to find another job. Wage is good but take home pay is way to low for what you do. Needle pokes, wasp attacks rolled ankles 15,000 to 20,000 kg BY HAND a day in the summer every day. Expected to pick up the slack for poor workers on top of your own work. This is one of the few cities left that still hand collects with no sign of it ever changing all the leaders and management only care about their own jobs and not their workers. The only way to get ahead is to kiss but and have no opinions to make changes they want everything to stay the same.

Municipal governments are a great place to work. You are provided a high level of job security, pension and benefits. However, the wages are just not comparable with the private sector. Couple that with the reduced working hours and the wage rate really starts to suffer. Lots of levels of management as well that one has to deal with which can be frustrating.

My typical day at work is getting prepared for the day with morning meetings ie; safety talks and concerns. I have gained a great knowledge of the city and the parking By-Laws and I have a great team of people to work with. The hardest part is dealing with the aggressive people and the threats of bodily harm to myself and other co-workers,but for the most part dealing with the public has been very enjoyable. The most enjoyable part is helping people.
pros: Company B.B.Q's, staff with good Sense of humor.
cons: there are none except maybe a better pay ;)

Excellent workplace. Enjoy the people. Hardest part of the job is maintaining the equipment.
I work hard everyday and finish project on time. But I still can not get a permenent position in it. Realy upset!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I am currently employed as a hd mechanic on the fleet services side have worked there for more then five years. Have on many occasions experienced intimidation and been threatened by foreman. Management isnt concerned with this as it has been an ongoing problem for years. Supervisors are yes men for upper management and will smile and look into anything you suggest to your face but behind closed doors there is a different attitude.there are some good supervisors as well but they have little ability it seems to act on problems either due to a high level of work they need to accomplish or tired of dealing with the same problem and seeing no results. They do have some excellent mechanics working for them but do not give them the opportunity to advance unless they learn to do favors for there superiors in management. Your more valuable as a mechanic then in a leadership role if you are a knowledgeable mechanic. Almost all in management are there due to either belonging to a small group of people that know someone or are willing to become yes men and will do whatever they can to get a shot at belonging to this group including doing personal favors after hrs for there superiors. Or have been injured working on the shop floor and taken the city foremanship training. Your not promoted due to being a highly qualified mechanic. There is poor communication skills with mechanics and workers but excellent with management when referring to foreman. Shift work is required and the shift differential is $1.10/ hr as compared to more then $5 with other employers. Wages are average so no compliant - more...
pros: average pay, pension plan, three weeks holidays after eleven month temp, if a permanent position is posted
cons: shiftwork, including having to cover shifts, due to not enough mechanics to cover shifts this is partially due to high turnover rate, little to no information on equipment, such as service manuals, as well as tooling they say they supply, poor management skills at foreman level, very disorganized, and have experienced and witnessed foreman using intimidation tactics on serviceman

text: At the City, you know you're never going to be emotionally babysat. There are always many levels of management above you, which ensures that your ego is likely to never get out of control.That being said, people at the section level tend to form close-knit teams and support each other. If you can find a spot like that, you're golden.
Management is really bad, Pay is alight, good work life balance, very old school, management is not progressive minded, fails to value good employee, lots of unnecessary politics

A typical day at work involves a lot of interaction with customers and coworkers, which I particularly enjoy.I've learned how to deal and serve all different types of customers in a respectful and enjoyable manner.There is a lot of respect and diversity amongst my coworkers, which makes going to work the more enjoyable.The hardest part of the job is having to deal with unreasonable customers from time to time.On the other hand, the overall customer service component of the job is the most enjoyable part of the job for me. I enjoy the personal interaction and the knowledge that a customer is happy because of my expertise and know-how of my job.
cons: lay off every year for temporary positions.

text: Having worked for the City for a number of years I can say that morale is very good which is a big key for a good working environment.Like most local governments the IT is well behind the times but the willingness to innovate is a very positive aspect.The benefits are very nice and as you are in a union position the pay has been on par or better than a private employer.
pros: decent break time, web policies and great work environment
